reviewText: Composed  by Gaetano Donizetti, with  librettist Salvatore Cammarano, "Roberto Devereux" is  a "tragedia lirica" -  or tragic opera  - inspired by the  play "Elisabethd`Angleterre"  by French author Frances Ancelot.  Lead female artist  is  the jealous Regina Elisabetta I  d'Inghilterra who signs the death warrant of  title  character  Roberto Devereux, Earl of Essex.  She does so after learning that  Roberto, her  younger lover (by more than  three decades!!!!), has fallen in love with another woman.  Later  she regrets her decision and tries to call off the execution, only to learn  that it is too late:  Roberto  is already dead.  Devastated by the news,  Elisabetta gives up the  throne in favor of her son  Giacomo and spends the rest of her life grieving for her former lover.Queen Elisabeth,  Robert Devereux, and the rest of the characters in the opera are real.  So are the  events, although not always  historically accurate.  So, let us make a quick digression and  learn  about  our two main characters and their lives, as described  in  the historical  documents.HISTORICAL DIGRESSION.  Elizabeth Tudor  or Elisabeth I (1533-1603), queen at the age of 25, inherited a  nation which, in addition to being bankrupt, was torn by  conflicts.  Rather than marrying and relying on her husband for support,  she  preferred to rule alone  - thus her nickname "The Virgin Queen" -  which she did for  nearly half a century, entirely  committed  to preserving peace and stability for her country.  She was successful in her effort and is today considered by many as the greatest monarch in English history.  Robert Devereux, second earl of Essex  (1565- 1601), was a member of the British aristocracy and  a relative of  the Queen,  his maternal great-grandmother having been Mary Boleyn,  sister of Anne Boleyn who was the mother of Queen Elizabeth I.  Apparently  very ambitious, he  led a rebellion against the Queen  in February 1601 and attempted to seize control of the City of London.  The rebellion failed and Robert was arrested, convicted of treason and sentenced to death, the warrant  signed by  Queen Elizabeth herself.  Dressed in black,  with a bright red waistcoat, Robert  was executed at the Tower of London on February 25 1601. Over 100 people witnessed the execution during which  three strokes of the axe were needed to sever his head.  It is reported that the  Queen may have signed the  death warrant, but  grieved deeply following  Robert 's  death, which  in fact troubled her until her own demise, two years later.  There are few official documents confirming  a personal  relationship  between Elisabeth and Robert,  but the queen's  grief  suggests a  closer bond than the one  between  her  and  a  much younger rebel  relative.Back to the opera."Roberto Devereux" -  first performed on 29 October 1837 at the Teatro San Carlo in Naples -  was an immediate  success.  The premiere was followed by performances  in most major European and American cities including Paris, London, Rome, Palermo and  New York City.  It was  forgotten after 1882,  then  revived  in 1964, again at the Teatro San Carlo in Naples.  It is now  included  in  the operatic repertoires both in Europe and in North America -  with and without the other two operas in Donizetti's  "Tudors Trilogy", "Anna Bolena" and  "Maria Stuarda".  It  is available  in various interpretations in DVD and CD formats.  The version  reviewed here  was recorded at the Teatro Donizetti  in Bergamo, the composer's  birth place and home town."Roberto Devereux"  is a beautiful opera, there is no doubt about it.  And - as some of the other reviewers have already recognized - is beautifully presented  and interpreted  by  Dimitra Theodossiou as Elisabetta, and Massimilano Pisapia as Roberto,  with the  Orchestra and Corus of the Bergamo Musica Festival, Marcello Rota, conductor.But - even keeping in mind the poetic licenses  allowed to  the opera composers and other artists - there are some peculiarities  here that one cannot help noticing.  First of all, along with the language,  the first names -  Roberto, Elisabetta, Sara - are Italian.  Yet  the characters  are  British and have  British last names or places of origin.Gaetano Donizetti wrote more than one opera whose title and other characters have  Italian first names and British  last names or places of origin.  For example, Lucia di Lammermoor, Francesca Fox, Elisabetta al Castello di Kenilworth.  Such a practice  is not common with other composers who wrote operas set in countries other than their own, even those who kept the libretto in their own language.Another peculiarity  is in that it is not  just the events that are historically inaccurate.  The temperaments are  inaccurate as well.The passions and emotions of Donizetti's  characters are  too intense for  the self-controlled  and  generally less emotional people from the British Isles.  Elisabetta of "Roberto  Devereux"  may have lived back in the 16th century - along with the rest of the  characters -  but she  is not the Queen Elisabeth  about whom we read in  the history books.  She is  a woman  with many strong emotions and little rationality.  She is jealous, she is angry at her lover who has dared to turn his attention to another woman.  Magnificently  interpreted by Dimitra Theodossiou - and  a little like Puccini's Tosca -  Elisabetta  is  thoroughly  Italian, with her lack of  control over her own life and  the lives of others.  To the point that she signs her lover's  death warrant, only to repent and try to call off the execution,  after receiving  a slight indication that the man may still care for  her.  Very effective in an opera, such  type of  temperament  is not the one typical  of  a British individual, certainly not of a queen..........,  not one who went down in history with a nickname  such as "The Virgin Queen"!!!Could there be reasons for  these peculiarities?  Perhaps yes, if we  look at Donizetti's background.  His grandfather, Donald Izet, moved from Scotland to Italy during the first half of the 18th century, at which time he  Italianized his name from Don Izet to Donizetti.  Although an Italian citizen, and clearly with a 100 per cent Italian temperament - grandson Gaetano must have  felt a connection to the British Isles, and may have  wanted for his British characters  a double nationality as well.  Thus he gave them  Italian first names -  and  emotions!!! -  and  British last names.Possible?  It is something for Donizetti's fans to ponder about.

reviewText: Roberto Deveruex is a masterpiece that grows on the listener - the rewards, like listening to musical masterpieces in general, are cathartic and long-lasting. As an opera, Devereux may not appeal to the ears immediately but repeated listening and a greater understanding of the work and its contextual genesis would quickly reveal it as Donizetti's arguably greatest dramatic opera.I have discussed the work in my earlier reviews of the other operatic productions; the merits need not be further extolled. When commercially available productions are hard to come by, it is apparent I would not let this one up.By and large I have read praise for Dimitra Theodossiou. Listening to samples of her singing elsewhere had convinced me that she might be close to the Elisabetta that I had in mind. Theodossiou's matronly appearance and strong features easily lands her in the physical role of Elizabeth I. Her tessitura (voice timbre) is also well-suited to the role - weightier and darker than Sills' or Gruberova's, making her version somewhat more vengeful and repressed. While this merits a very positive comparison, I was suspecting a draw somewhere - and my suspicions were confirmed while watching the production.To side-track a little, someone once opened up an interesting perspective regarding the choices that performing artists have to adopt; choices of artistry that balances the artist's personal ability and musical integrity in a performance, through the risks that an artist chooses to take. A pianist could choose pieces that he or she is comfortable enough to perform in a recital that is worthy of public scrutiny. With a coloratura opera singer, there seems to be more leeway, due to the improvisatory nature of the art. In this production, Theodossiou has chosen to keep the improvisatory passagework to a minimum - a conscious choice she has adopted for various reasons known to herself. Listening to the virtuosic cabaletta in Act I reveals this - she omits some runs and embellishments (so wonderfully wrought in Sills and Gruberova) quite to my disappointment, though this is probably a result of the expectation I had after listening to the two great coloraturas.Theodossiou is nonetheless a brilliant singer who has a singing style and timbre close to Callas (Greek, like Theodossiou herself); if not as forceful and compelling, she is still quite in her own league. However if one is expecting much coloratura and embellished singing in this production one would be duly disappointed. Theodossiou has either made a conscious choice to miminimize coloratura singing to carry the melodic line safely throughout her performance, or it could be simply that coloratura singing is not her forte. This is where Sills and Gruberova 'fills in the lack', even though neither's timbre is as dark as Theodossiou's, as one would conventionally expect from the role. While Theodossiou may not be as caressing or sympathy-inducing in the more heart-wrenching pieces as Sills or Gruberova, she sings them with enough empathy and duly makes it up in the more dramatic moments.Theodossiou has all the extravagance of drama expected of the role. For a more subtle and psychological interpretation one could look to Gruberova. There could even be a hint of over-acting, a part where she violently (or quite farcically) threw a chair in a fit of anger when Roberto refuses to confess the name of her love rival. Otherwise, Theodossiou gives a very credible portrayal of the role.The production set is conservative, but to this end all necessary care and moderation was tastefully taken to avoid the over-lavishness of certain productions that possibly occlude or distract from the merits of the singing and acting. Theodossiou's Elisabetta has three costume set changes; the first a ravishing white that immiediately establishes her presence on stage and the red costume that symbolically represents her vengeance and jealousy that entails in Act II as she denounces Roberto and signs his death warrant. The last reveals her in dark solemn gown 'sans' wig, symbolic of her waning power.The other singers should be given due credit as well. Sara the Duchess, sang by Frederica Bragargia, has a resonant voice that belies her thin frame, and she sings and acts the role competently and admirably. Massimiliano Pisapia as Roberto, if not quite convincing in appearance to merit the love of the two ladies in power, sings and acts competently as well but on a personal note, I found his voice a little shrill and thin for my liking. American baritone Andrew Schroeder as Nottingham is excellent here - he could very well be the best singer of the cast. Tenor Luigi Albani who sang Lord Cecil offers very raw singing and acting, but the role itself exerts the least demands dramatically and vocally among the cast.The orchestra under Marcello Rota offers top-notch and sensitive playing, if not quite as dramatic and tightly-paced as Friedrich Haider and the Bayerische Staats Orchestra in the 2005 production featuring Edita Gruberova. Another 'minus' would be the omission of the wonderful overture, apologetically but casually explained to be unrecorded or unplayed for the reason it was not written together with the opera by Donizetti.Another major consideration to purchase this version of the opera - the cataclysmic finale of ACT II is thankfully performed in its entirety and a few crucial bars of the coda/cadenza sung by the ensemble was carried through with aplomb, restoring the scene to its rightful dramatic intensity. In the Cristof Loy production of 2005 featuring Gruberova, these crucial bars were sadly omitted, leaving the music sounding rather truncated. The studio recording made with Haider conducting some years before also suffered this abominable cut for reasons I cannot fathom.There is every reason for this version of Roberto Devereux to be in the library of any lover of this opera as a contrasting yet moving production to the productions with Gruberova or Sills. On a note, if there were 4.5 stars, I would have given it in my review.
summary: A worthy set of Devereux to bestow your senses

reviewText: Firstly, let me point out the dictionary definition of "mediocre": "of only moderate quality". That sums up this production of Roberto Devereux: the production is OK, but not great, the singing is workmanlike, but not especially impressive (NB: I'm not an expert in singing technique), and the opera itself has its moments of musical beauty, but does not deeply move me or effect me.Theodossiou may well be the best Elizabeth one can want (again, I'm no aficionado), but her singing is unpleasant to *look* at: she juts out her bottom jaw--to produce an adequate tone, I presume--in a manner that accentuates her already harsh makeup.  Bragaglia is better to look at, and pleasant enough to look at and listen to as Sara. Pisapia as Devereux does a serviceable job, but I think one of my fellow reviewers goes overboard in his praising him. The best actor among the bunch is Schroeder as the Duke of Nottingham.UPDATE: I have watched it a second time, trying to verify and evaluate my previous response. I am convinced that much of my reaction is a reaction to Theodossiou's singing. Unlike my fellow reviewers, I simply do not find it beautiful. And indeed, one reviewer admits it may be "shrill." Precisely. She screeches rather than sings. (I will affirm their approbation of her ACTING.) Some of the music--especially the ensembles--is beautiful, but I cannot get past Theodossiou's voice. [end update]All opera buffs know opera plots--especially in the bel canto repertoire--should not be investigated too closely. But I'm still trying to figure out the "magic" ring that Devereux is supposed to produce in order to save his life: If the Queen knows he has the ring, why does she have to wait for someone to produce it in order to forgive him? It is not as if the ring comes from *someone else*, whose judgment the Queen is depending upon.Oh well. More of some dramatic quality--better acting, a more attractive set, more beautiful singing, *something*--would compensate for such a lapse in plotting. That something is lacking. Unless you are a bel canto aficionado, or must have Donizetti's Tudor  "trilogy" (Devereux, Anna Bolena, Maria Stuarda), I would pass.
summary: An adequate production of a mediocre opera

reviewText: It is hard to decide which is the best one between this DVD and the one with Alexandrina Pendatchanska as Elisabetta. They are both great.But were are now speaking of the Dimitria Theodossiou's.I was very impressed by her voice and acting ability, she is good throughout the entire performance.The final scene is certainly exciting,but Act II is also a great piece of theatre as well as musically; Elisabetta's confrontation with Robertoin which she tells him "It had been better for you to have descended  alive to your grave before crossing the daughter of awesome Henry VIII" is hair raising. In that makeup she reminds me of Bette Davis (Those old enough to remember the film classic "The Private Lives of Elizabeth and Essex" will know what I mean) unfortunately this Roberto does not look like Errol Flynn, but his tenor certainly have the right stuff for this heroic part.I found the entire production very satisfying, the sets were sparse,yet tasteful and the costumes were beautiful. Too bad that the Bavarian State opera did not rent or borrowed this production for the Gruberova DVD!!Now, if you are a fan of Beverly Sills, which I am, you should also getthe DVD of her performance at Wolf Trap,however the sound is far from great and Miss Sills vocal gifts were already on the decline at the time of this performance, but if you are a fan,the DVD is a must.

reviewText: Here in this obscure production,this "Roberto Devereux", I absolutely assure you, that you will hear some of the most beautiful music ever composed by mere mortal man.Some of us are aware of Donizetti's masterpiece of opera buffa, "L'Elisir d'Amore", particularly the production with Roberto Alagna and his stunning wife Angela Gheorgiu. And we are also aware that Donizetti lost all three of his children to death, and his wife, and he himself died a slow and terrible death. Do you think Donizetti could write an opera seria with unimaginable pathos and eloquence? I think so, don't you?Moreover, who among us has heard of Dimitra Theodossiou?  Yet this performance of hers in this production cannot possibly be surpassed by anyone past or present or future. If I were a soprano, and was assigned this role of Queen Elizabeth, I'd wake up in a cold sweat of fear, and dread of the demand that was about to be placed upon me in order to successfully sing this role...and oh brother does she sing. It is slack jaw, heaving breast astonishment to behold. A skinny kid could not possibly accomplish this. In the final scenes where her gown and queen wig is removed, revealing her maturity, her lovely silver hair...then you understand how such a tour de force like this is accomplished. She simply has the range and power, and deepness to do this. I am now looking for more works with Dimitra in them. I have one...an old  Mascagni production,( Mascagni  of "Cavaleria Rusticana" fame). But in this Mascagni, she co stars with Jose Bros. I really like Jose Bros-tremendous voice!...but he is not much of an actor-either that, or he has never had much in the way of a great director. I have this certain audacity of straining at the bit to take over as art director of every opera i see...and this old one I have  with Jose and Dimitria is one I wish I could completely re-do....I hardly noticed Dimitria in that production. Not because she failed to deliver...No, dear souls; it was the artistic direction that  failed.In this Donizetti production, however,  the set and direction allowed Dimitra to display her resplendent talents to the absolute stellar maximum.I'm running out of space here, so i must close with the highest accolade  and approbation of the romantic lead, Massimiliano Pisapia. Words are stupid things, one wag said once, and now  I must borrow the phrase in my attempt to describe the perfection of this man's voice. I honestly have not heard a more perfect tenor anywhere, in any  production! If you are not moved to tears by his great cry of love for the duchess, in act three,  scene 20, "Come un spirito angelico"...you need to be slapped awake with a bucket of cold water dashed against your numb face, for you are probably near dead. This is a great tenor... he has a great barrel chest, which provides the power, the sustain, the resonance, and the melifluous tonality, and breathtaking sensitivity, the soto voce,  oh, that this man possesses in spades.
